{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3372733,"name":"Dan_Karol","username":"Dan_Karol","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dan_karol/{size}/227378_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T21:42:55.350Z","cooked":"

The official season is over, it’s time for our CAD release!

To save time, we only fully populated 1 side when we had symmetrical mechanisms, so if something looks weird, please look at both sides. This is especially true on the lift.

cad.onshape.com

Onshape

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

This robot is divided into 3 major subsystems:

  1. The Drive
    This subsystem includes our Bumpers, Electronics, and Intake. Fun Fact: We had initially dismissed an under-the-bumper intake, but revisited it when 95 posted in their build thread and we saw how much harder an over-the-bumper intake made integration for us. If you haven’t seen their build thread, you should check it out here.
  2. The Lift
    This Subsystem was inspired by 4414’s 2023 Lift. There are some key differences. We were unable to purchase the WCP inline bearing block for elevators so we designed for the clamping bearing blocks instead. This lead us down some interesting rabbit holes related to lift distance efficiency. The clamping bearing blocks don’t sit as close to the ends of the lift and thus limit the range of the carriage more than the inline versions. After some carful study we were able to move the pulley supports to inside the tubing allowing the carriage to move up through the full extent of the middle stage. This results in a lift that has excellent travel given it’s overall size. The lift includes notches to pull the chain down to initiate a climb.
  3. The Launcher
    This subsystem centers and indexes notes, launches them and scores in the Amp and Trap. The outer roller was made independent between Week 0 and Week 1 to allow us to score in the Trap by pushing the note out the top of launcher instead of the bottom. After we fixed some of our height efficiency issues that we had at Week 0, we didn’t need this feature, but kept the roller because it allowed us to receive a note directly from a human player. In earlier versions the outer roller was powered by the same Vortex Motor as the other rollers. We deigned the launcher to allow us to put spin on the note, but never ended up using it.

In general, this robot was highly robust and required less maintenance than almost any other robot we have fielded.

As always our code is never hidden and available here:

GitHub

CHAOS 131

FRC Team 131. CHAOS 131 has 25 repositories available. Follow their code on GitHub.

I would also like to take the opportunity to remind everyone that our hoodie fundraiser will be open for oders until May 10th 2024. You can get yours here:

docs.google.com

CHAOS 131 Hoodie Order Form

Thank you for your interest in our new CHAOS hoodies! We are ordering a limited run as a fundraiser. All proceeds will directly support CHAOS's travel to the World Championship in Houston, Texas April 17-20, 2024. Hoodies are $45. They can be...

Thanks James! I hope we can chat at some off-seasons.

This was certainly a “Push Hard” sort of season. The team is simultaneously energized and exhausted. I’m always in awe of the teams that have the energy to participate in Open Alliance during build season.
